title: Ticket #7021: Declare build products from external projects
description:
Suppose we have this setup:

  1. We have an external project, foo, in the Condor build,
  2. The foo target produces as part of the build a library libfoo.so, and
  3. There is a condor executable condor_foo that links against libfoo.so.

In this case, some build generators (particularly, ninja) fail. This is because ninja will analyze the entire build dependency graph prior to starting the build and bail out if there are unmet dependencies.

make, on the other hand, is lazy. It does not compute dependencies until it tries to build a given target. So if there's an undeclared side-product (as is the situation above), make won't notice unless the external project build is not complete by time it tries to build condor_foo.

This is why make is "normally happy" but, on large machines with lots of parallelism, we have to do make externals followed by make: we have missing dependencies and the build system doesn't get the ordering correct. We are simply lucky that, for example, all the CREAM dependencies are normally done by time the cream_gahp is linked.

CMake 3.x fixes this by adding a BUILD_BYPRODUCTS attribute - you can declare what files the external project will generate and CMake can generate the dependencies accordingly.

We can't assume CMake 3.x however; we are stuck on 2.x. I propose adding a custom target in condor_post_external that has the same side-effect as what CMake 3.x does internally.
